resource.chars:
into white and black Rings, and afterwards into colours againe in an 
inverted Order; it must be remembred, that those colours are dilated 
by the Obliquac[i]on of the rayes to the Air wch intercedes the glasses,
& that according to the Table in the 7th Observac[i]on their dilatac [i]on 
or recession from their comon Center is most manifest and Speedy 
when they are obliquest. Now the rayes of yellow, being more 
refracted by the first Superficies of the said air then those of Red,
are thereby made more Oblique to the Second Superficies, at wch 
they are reflected to produce the coloured Ringes, & consequently 
the yellow in each Ring will be more dilated then the Red, &
the excess of its dilatac[i]on will be so much the greater, by how 
much the greater is the Obliquity of the rayes, untill at last 
it become of equall Extent with the Red of the same Ring.
And for the same reason the Green, Blew & Violet will be alsoe 
so much dilated by the still greater Obliquity of their rayes, as 
to become all very nearly of equall extent with the Red, that is,
equally distant from the Center of the Rings. And then all the 
colours of the Same Series must be coincident, and by their 
mixture exhibit a white Ring. And these white Rings must 
haue black or dark Rings between them, because they do not spread 
& interfere with one another as before; And for that reason also 
they must become distincter and visible to farr greater Numbers.
But yet the violet, being Obliquest, will be something more dilated 
in proporc[i]on, then the other colours, & So very apt to appear at the 
exterior Verges of the white 
Afterwards, by a great[e]r obliquity of the Rayes, the Violet and 
the Blew become Sensibly more dilated then the Red & yellow, &
Soe being further removed from the Center of the Ringes, the colours 
must emerge out of the white in an Order contrary to that wch they had 
before, the Violet and Blew at the exterior Limbs, and the Red, &
yellow at the interior. And the Violet by reason of the greatest 
Obliquity of its Rayes, being in proportion most of all expanded, will 
Soonest appeare at the exterior limb of each white ring, & become 
more conspicuous then the rest. And the Seu[er]al Series of Colours 
by their unfolding & Spreading will begin again to interfere, and 
thereby render the rings lesse distinct, & not visible to So great 
Numbers.
If, instead of the Prisms, the Object Glasses be made use of,
the Rings, wch they Exhibit, become not white & distinct by ye Obliquity 
of the Eye, by reason that the rayes in their passage through that 
Air
